comments.commentBody: If the Confederacy had prevailed, it would have still been abominable and slavery WOULD have lasted well into the 20th century and de facto slavery existed in the South until the 1960s.  The USA had hardly been the most exemplary nation in world history, but the CSA was far worse.  BTW, although I was born iin and lived much of my early life in California, many of my ancestors were Southerners during the period of the Civil War, and my Baptist minister maternal grandfather was born in Vicksburg, Mississippi, in 1898.  Regardless, I don't engage in ancestor worship.  The South was wrong.

I think there is a valid argument that the Confederate national government centralized power to a greater degree than the US government did, during the war. They extra-legally squashed local, autonomous movements (or at least attempted to) in western Virginia (soon to be West Virginia), east Tennessee, western North Carolina, northern Alabama, and northern Arkansas. They enacted a more draconian conscription law even earlier than the Union. They jailed dissidents without due process; as Lincoln had his Vallandigham, so too did Davis have his Parson Brownlow.

The Davis administration took over the day-to-day operations of industries from firearms production to lead mining, salt, cotton, etc. Though cut off from much contact with, or direction from Richmond, after Vicksburg & Port Hudson, Gen. Kirby Smith exercised even stronger "federal" powers in the Trans-Mississippi.

President Obama has bemoaned his inability to exercise executive fiat so unilaterally. A "progressive" leader as he is would love to be able to emulate "Kirby-Smithdom", in that respect, at least.

While not dead, competition is much impaired, which raise this question: To the extent competition is impaired, and it is greatly impaired, what of the benefits of competition which are supposed to be essential to prosperity and equity. Lawyers and economist learn that from pervasive and vigorous competition flows restraint on excessive profits, increase in alternatives and choices in the marketplace, increased consumer welfare is maximized as monopoly rents are precluded and the market sets prices at the level of the most efficient producers, innovation is spurred as firms attempt to acquire greater than market rents for more competitive goods and services, the quality of goods and services is enhanced as firm must compete on quality, and many competing firms should diminish firms' monopsony power in labor markets, risks to the economy should also be reduces as firms constitute smaller shares of their various markets, firms undue political power is diminished as competition restrains their size and wealth, and etc.

So, if vigorous and pervasive competition has faded, haven't the foregoing benefits of competition also faded?

She beamed and said "I love your site, xxx.com why don't you blog for.me?" I knew better to pursue the conversation. Journalism and the craft of writing has been gutted by the likes of her. You want free content? You get what you pay for. Some do it better than others, but in the end, the smart ones are like "Oliver's" Fagin luring kids into indentured servitude.

I note that conservative leaders are saying that the main reason the Obama recovery has been sooooo slow is because of "regulatory overreach." They are not mentioning inflation.

I don't want inflation because people on fixed incomes, who can least afford it, don't need inflation. Some government policy types in the Congress were worried about interest rates rising and what it would do to the annual amount of government revenues would be required to service the interest on the debt.

I think the US markets are flooded with cheap goods and noone even thinks about inflation. I am surprised that Dr. Feldstein even bothers to write about inflation.

I think we need to worry about the stagnation in wages and the economy in general, for the short term, and how we are going to shift away from fossil fuels in the mid and long-term.

Kudos to Prof. Finkelman and many of the commenters for engaging in a full blown, lively discussion of the quintessential defining issues of our Nation. Given such passionate erudition, why have we failed, as an electorate, to dismantle the entrenched gerrymandered demagoguery of mediocre politicians? Is it mere apathy, shortsighted self-interest, misdirected regional pride, maddening rugged individualism? There seems to be a sinister element in our national ethos. That which shot us to the Moon, yet drags us into political neglect, even drives us to adopt self-defeating policies. The fraticidal and brutal Civil War may have been inevitable, but today what is so?

Is that why the 1% are so upset, cranky, condescending, obtuse, arrogant;  the inflation in their world bubble?  I am sure the family whose car just broke down, who are up late at night trying to figure out how to get to work the next days, is very concerned about the price of a new piece of art.  I guess we should be thinking that if art was less, then the CEO wouldn't need as high a salary and that savings would be put to an increase in the pay for the worker so they could fix their car?

@J Sturm

It is immaterial how inflation is "traditionally measured". You need to measure what is happening in today's economy.

There is s decoupling between GDP increase and median income increase. Similarly, there is a decoupling between monetary base expansion and broad consumer spending.

The phenomenons are the same. The GDP gains and central bank liquidity are ending up in much, much fewer hands. So, instead of seeing an increase in the price of toilet paper and socks, you see an increase in the price of high end real estate, stocks, bonds, Picassos, etc.

It is inflation just the same. It is simply inflation on the asset classes that the wealthy invest in/purchase vs what the average Joe purchases.

Dr. Krugman wants to completely ignore asset price inflation, which is where all this newly printed money is going. To the delight of the financial institutions and the wealthy.
If CEO salaries weren't so high, art wouldn't be so high.

Prof Krugman, disingenuously, continues to equate inflation with CPI increases.

If the excess liquidity was broadly distributed to consumers, it would be reflected in CPI increase or consumer inflation.

Since the excess liquidity is virtually all concentrated into financial institutions and the wealthy, it is being reflected in asset price increases, or asset price inflation.

The newly minted money is inflating the price of apartments in NYC and London, stock markets and bond prices everywhere, gold, art, etc. Virtually everything the wealthy put their money on, is increasing in price massively.
No loss at all. If it falls off the face of the earth, would anyone notice?

Come on. These analysts are kids who worked hard to get opportunities that they thought would further their careers. You aren't seriously suggesting that they deserved their deaths are you? Who did THEY oppress? I am all for less pressure on single moms but your argument just doesn't seem to care for excellence. The real casualty of this mess on Wall Street is excellence. I hope their parents bring about a civil suit that makes Goldman and Moelis look up.

Ludicrous demands aren't limited to Wall Street. In many realms, including law, education and primary care medicine, managers who don't really know or care how demanding the work is are pushing (and are probably pushed to demand) more hours, more work than is humanly possible on a sustainable basis. The focus on the bottom line--no doubt in part because of the proliferation of MBAs--is short-sighted.

Some of us are lucky enough to have a terrific work-life balance and are also very high performers at our jobs.  The key: find an employer that values competence and productivity over face time, and don't expect to achieve great wealth, which is unnecessary for happiness.

With your first point, you are correct. However, the dream is arguably still reflect conflicting feelings, especially in light of the author's earlier indication of his initial attraction to Beatrice. It's not particularly important and I should been more careful in my reading and have edited it out.

Your second point is also insightful. We obviously rely on many ongoing professional relationships throughout our lives, and if this were about an accountant, or, a better analog, a lawyer, there would be no objection. For better or worse, I believe we still preserve a special status for emotional attachment and deep intimacy, hence the strict ethical boundaries.

Perhaps our is a philosophical difference. I believe that virtually every person who is on par emotionally as the author can learn to cope with life in a finite period of time. The saying about th value of teaching a person to fish as opposed to simply giving them one is a close approximation. Emotional skills are still learned skills. How long does it take to learn an emotional skill to the point that it does not have to be reinforced consistently? yes, of course, a lifetime. Reinforced by a professional psychotherapist? Gone fishing'.

Goodbye Instagram.

I'm still failing to see the issue here. Why do you feel entitled to use a company's service for free at the expense of that company? Facebook bought Instagram for a substantial amount of money and finally has the tools to make revenue out of Instagram. What's the problem with that? Calling Instagram part of the "breeding ground for a bunch of sheep" is hardly fair (just like your entire assessment of how our economy works). Companies invest in a product. Companies attempt to make money out of a product, as is their right. That's just how the world works.
